headlines.title: Chargers outduel Chiefs 27–21 in Brazil to open NFL season
Eagles edge Cowboys 24–20 in lightning-delayed Kickoff game
Worlds Tokyo 2025: Why Melissa Jefferson‑Wooden is the 100m favorite

stories.title: Brazil opener: Herbert, Chargers stun Chiefs 27–21
stories.body:
The NFL’s first regular‑season game in Brazil delivered a jolt: Justin Herbert threw for 318 yards
and                 three touchdowns as the Los Angeles Chargers beat the Kansas City Chiefs 27–21
at São Paulo’s                 Neo Química Arena. Herbert’s late first‑down scramble helped bleed
the clock after the Chiefs cut the                 lead to six, snapping L.A.’s seven‑game skid to
their AFC West rivals. The opener also marked the                 league’s expansion push into South
America, drawing a raucous, soccer‑style crowd and global                 attention.
Beyond the scoreline, the game offered storylines for Week 1 and beyond. Chiefs WR Xavier Worthy
exited with a shoulder injury and will be evaluated stateside, while an on‑field dust‑up between
Chargers DT Teair Tart and Travis Kelce briefly overshadowed the action. For L.A., new head coach
Jim Harbaugh’s balanced attack featured timely shots to Quentin Johnston and Keenan Allen plus
clock‑milking runs to close. For Kansas City, Patrick Mahomes extended plays as usual but faced
pressure in high‑leverage moments, a trend to watch as the Chiefs try to three‑peat.
The Brazil debut checked the NFL’s boxes: big‑market buzz, compelling finish, and star power. If the
Bolts sustain this formula, the AFC West may be more open than assumed.

stories.title: Kickoff classic: Eagles hold off Cowboys 24–20 after long weather delay
stories.body:
The Super Bowl champion Eagles opened their title defense with a 24–20 win over the Cowboys in a
lightning‑delayed thriller at Lincoln Financial Field. Jalen Hurts powered Philadelphia with two
rushing touchdowns and a turnover‑free night, while the defense flipped the script after halftime
and                 pitched a shutout down the stretch. A 65‑minute delay froze the scoreboard at
24–20 late in the third,                 and when play resumed, Philly’s front sealed it with
pressure and sure tackling.                                  Dallas showed flashes in Brian
Schottenheimer’s head‑coaching debut—more motion, play‑action and                 discipline—but
critical fourth‑quarter drops derailed a potential comeback. Even so, the Cowboys
allowed zero sacks and kept the run game viable, hints that this offense can be more multiple in
2025.                 For the champs, the opener showcased a familiar formula: Hurts’ red‑zone
solving, situational defense,                 and special‑teams steadiness. Circle the rematch; the
NFC East race looks spicy already.

stories.title: Tokyo 100m preview: Why we’re picking Melissa Jefferson‑Wooden for gold
stories.body:
The World Athletics Championships begin September 13 in Tokyo, and the women’s 100 meters has a
clear                 frontrunner on form: Melissa Jefferson‑Wooden. The U.S. sprint star swept the
100/200 at the USATF                 Championships, clocking 10.65—the world lead and fifth‑fastest
all time—then dominated Diamond League                 fields in Silesia and Brussels (10.76),
staying unbeaten at 100m this season. Factor in her relay gold                 pedigree and
increasingly sharper starts, and our pick is Jefferson‑Wooden to claim the ‘World’s
Fastest Woman’ title in Tokyo.                                  The field is stacked: reigning world
champion Sha’Carri Richardson remains dangerous, Britain’s                 Daryll Neita has trimmed
tenths, and Saint Lucia’s Julien Alfred lurks with big‑meet speed. Yet
Jefferson‑Wooden’s 2025 résumé blends raw time, championship reps, and tactical execution better
than                 anyone. Unless curveballs—weather, rounds fatigue, or a perfect‑start
rival—intervene, the tape points                 to Melissa on top in the National Stadium.

stories.title: Worlds preview: Melissa Jefferson‑Wooden’s golden path in Tokyo
stories.body:
Everything about Melissa Jefferson‑Wooden’s 2025 points to a peak timed for Tokyo: an undefeated
100m                 season, a U.S. title in a blazing 10.65 (No. 5 all‑time), and emphatic Diamond
League wins including                 Silesia and Brussels. The U.S. team is set, the timetable is
locked (Sept 13–21), and the National                 Stadium track is historically quick.
The threats are real—world champ Sha’Carri Richardson, Britain’s Daryll Neita, and Saint Lucia’s
Julien Alfred—but Jefferson‑Wooden’s starts, transition, and top‑end maintenance have been the best
in                 class. Our pick: gold in the 100m, with a shot at relay glory too.
